evidence_span: A 2-s heat-up to the desired temperature was followed by an isothermal hold for the desired time in steam flowing at 2.5 g/s (20 lb/h)

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: Sample temperature was measured by using a Pt/Pt-13Rh thermocouple welded to a protective tantalum isolation pad, which had previously been welded to the Zircaloy specimen

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: Accuracies of $\pm 1$ percent of the quoted temperature are claimed; that is, at $1 2 7 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 2 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$ , the accuracy is $\pm 1 4 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( \pm 2 5 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: the specimen heat-up procedure consisted of bringing the specimen to about $1 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ EY $( 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$ in air, admitting steam at a flow rate of $0 . 1 2 5 ~ \mathbf { g } / \mathbf { s }$ (1 lb/h), and then bringing the specimen to an intermediate hold temperature of about $3 1 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ EPY $( 6 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Because of preoxidation during extended heat-up periods, the analysis of oxide-stabilized α thickness ratios is not so straightforward as implied above.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: It was shown earlier that the presence of a prefilm affects the oxidation reaction kinetics.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: The presence of a prefilm in some oxidation experiments is suggested by nonzero intercepts in plots of the square of the layer thicknesses versus time.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Extended heat-up periods are indicated by the application of "effective time" at temperature corrections to the data, as was calculated by ORNL, CEGB, and JAERI.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: In the presence of temperature gradients, reported oxidation kinetics parameters wil also reflect the position on the specimen at which the temperature is monitored.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: The CEGB investigators monitored the temperature at the outside surface, while ORNL monitored the temperature at the inside surface.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Reference to Fig. 3a shows that individual data points from the former investigation consistently fall below the best-estimate straight line, while the converse applies to the latter set of data.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: The systematic deviations in these two sets of data are consistent with the view that a temperature gradient exists across the oxidizing layers such that, with external heating, the outside surface temperature is higher than the inside surface temperature.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Zircaloy specimens were filled with uranium dioxide pellets (and in two cases, alumina pellets) and pressurized with inert gas prior to being heated in a flowing steam environment.
specimen_state: filled with uranium dioxide pellets or alumina pellets
process_step: pressurized with inert gas, heated in flowing steam

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Rupture occurred during heating, and the ruptured specimen was then exposed to steam at the nominal test temperature.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: The initial internal pressure, the final hold temperature, and the overall duration of the run were the controlled test variables.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Data were obtained for 25 conditions.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: The inside-outside oxygen³ ratio was measured as a function of distance from the rupture and as a function of azimuthal position at a given elevation.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Specimens were examined at elevations of 0 cm, 5.1 cm (2 in.), and 10.2 cm (4 in.) above the center of the rupture.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: At each elevation, the oxide and stabilized α thicknesses were measured at four locations, 90 deg apart.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: The data to be reported for each position are the average values of the four individual measurements.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk7
evidence_span: JAERI reported significantly higher inside-outside oxygen absorption ratios than those obtained by BNWL. The average of all JAERI data (obtained from its published figures) was 1.37.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk7
evidence_span: This compares with an average value of 0.62 obtained by BNWL from measurements at the rupture elevation on specimens tested at $9 8 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 1 8 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$ .

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk7
evidence_span: The extreme case in the BNWL experiments was specimens exposed at $1 2 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 2 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ for $\mathfrak { 3 6 0 5 }$ The average value of the inside-outside oxygen absorption ratio at the rupture elevation was 1.14.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: The annealing periods varied between 3 and 60 min

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: UO₂ is partially reduced by Zircaloy at the high temperatures investigated

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: a (U-Zr)-alloy rich in uranium and an oxygen stabilized α-Zr(O) phase are formed

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: The degree of chemical interaction between UO₂ and Zircaloy is determined by oxygen diffusion in the Zircaloy and the α-Zr(O) phase formed

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: The UO₂-Zircaloy reactions obey a parabolic rate law whose temperature dependence is given in the corresponding Arrhenius plot

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: The formation of oxygen-stabilized α-Zr(O) implies heavy embrittlement of the Zircaloy cladding above 1200°C

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: Thin oxide layers on the cladding tube inner surface prevent UO₂/Zircaloy reactions from taking place below 1100°C

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_036_chunk8
evidence_span: Simulated fission products (cesium, iodine, tellurium) in UO₂ exert practically no influence on the extent of the reaction
